author: alexssd7fp
content:
If anyone is looking for the exact changes in how fees are awarded to the miner, see this piece of code from Geth:
```go
effectiveTip := st.gasPrice
if st.evm.ChainConfig().IsLondon(st.evm.Context.BlockNumber) {
    effectiveTip = cmath.BigMin(st.gasTipCap, new(big.Int).Sub(st.gasFeeCap, st.evm.Context.BaseFee))
}
st.state.AddBalance(st.evm.Context.Coinbase, new(big.Int).Mul(new(big.Int).SetUint64(st.gasUsed()), effectiveTip))
```
Or translated to python pseudocode:
```py
effectiveTip = tx.gasPrice
if isLondon(block.Number):
  effectiveTip = min(tx.gasPrice, (tx.gasPrice - block.baseFee))
state.addBalance(block.coinbase, receipt.gasUsed * effectiveTip)
```

author: alexssd7fp
content: Question: effectively, how much fees (in %) will be burnt on Ethereum considering that the block utilization will be on 100%?

author: timbeiko
content: It's hard to estimate, because MEV varies a lot here

author: timbeiko
content: Over the past ~2 weeks, the average profit from MEV for flashbot blocks is ~.1 ETH (https://dashboard.flashbots.net/miners)

author: timbeiko
content: There is a bundle in ~60% of blocks

author: timbeiko
content: So that means, extrapolating to 100% of blocks, MEV provides an extra ~.06 ETH per block

author: timbeiko
content: That's probably a good proxy for the sum of tips to miners per block

author: timbeiko
content: Over the past 2 weeks, there's been roughly 3k ETH in total txns fees per day, and there are ~6600 blocks per day, so ~.45 ETH per block

author: timbeiko
content: So I guess the lower bound would be that .06ETH of that .45ETH is not burnt and .39ETH (~86%) is burnt. I think this is probably the most bearish scenario for miners

author: timbeiko
content: Obviously, there is huge variance in all these numbers, so worth taking with a massive grain of salt and double-checking yourself <@!354681205842771973>

author: timbeiko
content: Oh, and this ignores the "default" tip for non-MEV transactions. If you assume 2 gwei here, and 15m gas, you get an extra .03 ETH per block, so that brings the total to .36/.45ETH burnt ~= 80%
